body_html:
okay, my bad I wrote in a confusing way, it should be in a tensor as well.
But the general concept of taking derivative respect to the input (here x) is the same.

Let me give you an example, we have a function

def f(x): return tf.reduce_mean(x,(0,1,2,),keep_dims=True)

so the output would be a tensor shape of (1,1,1,32) right?
But when we take the derivative respect to the original input x the derivative is 1/(10 * 94 * 94)
For all variable in x - so it would be a tensor that has a shape of (10,94,94,32) but every value would be
0.00001131733

I believe you know how to do these by hand right Yuxin?

I have attached some screenshots to help you understand what I mean.

body:
okay, my bad I wrote in a confusing way, it should be in a tensor as well.
But the general concept of taking derivative respect to the input (here x) is the same. 

Let me give you an example, we have a function 

def f(x): return tf.reduce_mean(x,(0,1,2,),keep_dims=True)

so the output would be a tensor shape of (1,1,1,32) right? 
But when we take the derivative respect to the original input x the derivative is 1/(10 * 94 * 94) 
For all variable in x - so it would be a tensor that has a shape of (10,94,94,32) but every value would be
0.00001131733

I believe you know how to do these by hand right Yuxin? 

I have attached some screenshots to help you understand what I mean. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22832406/48329606-7ff1f600-e617-11e8-994a-4309de03ed7e.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22832406/48329616-884a3100-e617-11e8-8038-f84bd34d72e7.png)
